bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: William Joseph Newman, a Utica, New York native, served his country in the United States Army. While attending John Carroll University in Cleveland, Ohio William became a commissioned officer in the ROTC. He completed his ten week orientation with the Transportation Corps at Fort Eustis, Virginia, and went on to serve in various assignments in Korea, including that of 1st Lieutenant with the 17th Transportation Battalion’s 7th Infantry Division. He served as a member of the 333rd Intelligence Detachment, and as 2nd Lieutenant and Platoon Leader with the Armored Personnel Carrier (APC) Company. William was promoted to Captain in 1965 during his assignment in Germany with the 92nd Company, 5th Corps. While stationed in Vietnam he served as Group Maintenance Officer for the 8th Group Motor Transport Unit, and as Company Commander of the 597th Company in the Qui Nhon valley in Vietnam.

William is the recipient of the Army Commendation Medal, the Reserves Achievement Medal, the National Defense Medal, Vietnam Service Medal, Overseas Service Medal, RUN Campaign Medal and the Korean Defense Medal among others.

scopecontent.head: Scope Note
scopecontent.p: This collection details William Joseph Newman’s experience during his enlistment in the Vietnam War as well as the years following. An interview was conducted on April 2, 2004 at William’s home by Eileen Hurst. The collection consists of the interview and a reproduction of the scanned interview synopsis detailing William’s military career and combat experiences. This oral history details William’s experiences in the military and offers insights into the responsibilities, concerns, and duties of Army officers in combat situations.

custodhist.head: Custodial History note
custodhist.p: All manuscripts and photographs donated were digitized and digitally preserved. The donor retained all original manuscripts and photographs.
